    46→
    47→PROBLEM SUMMARY
    48→ *  ****************************************************************
    49→   USERS AFFECTED:
    50→   This issue affects users of the WebSphere MQ V7.0.1.5 Classes
    51→   for Java/JMS (or later) who have established a remote connection
    52→   to a Queue Manager via a channel that has Conversation Sharing
    53→   disabled (SHARECNV=0 or SHARECNV=1).
    54→
    55→   This includes users of:
    56→
    57→   - The WebSphere MQ V7.0.1 Classes for JMS
    58→   - The WebSphere MQ V7.0.1 Resource Adapter.
    59→   - The WebSphere Application Server V7.0 and V8.0 WebSphere MQ
    60→   messaging provider.
    61→   - The WebSphere Application Server V6.1 WebSphere MQ messaging
    62→   provider who have configured the WebSphere variable
    63→   MQ_INSTALL_ROOT to point to a WebSphere MQ V7.0.1 installation.
    64→
    65→   Platforms affected:
    66→   All Distributed (iSeries, all Unix and Windows)
    67→   ****************************************************************
    68→   PROBLEM SUMMARY:
    69→   By default in the WebSphere MQ Classes for Java/JMS,
    70→   conversation
    71→   sharing is enabled and set to 10 on the client side. The client
    72→   only discovers that Conversation Sharing is disabled following
    73→   negotiation with a Queue Manager on the completion of a
    74→   connection over a Channel that has SHARECNV=0 or SHARECNV=1.
    75→
    76→   When a WebSphere MQ Classes for Java/JMS application requests a
    77→   remote connection to a Queue Manager the client first attempts
    78→   to find an already established TCP/IP connection which can be
    79→   shared. As part of this process the list of known TCP/IP
    80→   connections are matched for their suitability, this list
    81→   includes connections which are in the process of being
    82→   established (MQCONN reply not received from the Queue Manager).
    83→
    84→   When a WebSphere MQ Classes for Java/JMS application requested a
    85→   remote connection it was matched for sharing with a connection
    86→   that was still in the process of being established. The
    87→   WebSphere MQ Client waited for the connection to complete and
    88→   due to a small timing window began incorrectly sharing the
    89→   connection without confirming the connection's suitability. If
    90→   the connection's suitability had been checked then the
    91→   connection
    92→   would have been marked unsuitable due to the Negotiated Channel
    93→   specifying that Conversation Sharing was disabled (SHARECNV=0 or
    94→   SHARECNV=1).
    95→   As the connection (which did not support conversation sharing)
    96→   was now shared by two threads, packets destined for one thread
    97→   were erroneously received by the other, this led to the client
    98→   being in an inconsistent state and the two FDCs being generated.

    13→ When to enable Sharing Conversations in DataPower MQ Queue Manager (mq-qm) object along with SHARECNV attribute of the MQ SVRCONN channel?
    14→
    15→RESOLVING THE PROBLEM
    16→IBM WebSphere MQ server version 7.0 and later releases provide sharing conversations (SHARECNV) attribute on SVRCONN channel that specifies the maximum number of conversations that can share each TCP/IP channel instance. This feature can be configured in DataPower as it uses client connection with queue manager SVRCONN channel.
    17→The default setting of sharing conversations (SHARECNV) value is zero in DataPower mq-qm object. The same default value for MQ SVRCONN channel is 10. The sharing conversations value is
    18→negotiated between MQ server and DataPower and the lower value takes effect. However, in current versions of the DataPower firmware, the sharing conversations setting of 1 is treated as 0 when negotiating with MQ server.
    19→
    20→There are three use cases to configure Sharing Conversations in DataPower mq-qm object:
    21→
    22→Case #1 : The negotiated sharing conversations value is 0 - The channel runs in a mode similar to WebSphere MQ V6 and does not uses features such as
    23→
    24→· Administrator stop-quiesce
    25→· Heartbeating
    26→· Read ahead
    27→· Client asynchronous consume
    28→
    29→Set a value of 0 or 1 on the Sharing Conversations attribute of the mq-qm object in DataPower to disable sharing conversations regardless of the IBM WebSphere MQ SVRCONN setting.
    30→
    31→Case #2: The negotiated sharing conversations value is 1 - The channel supports IBM WebSphere MQ V7 and later release features as outlined in case #1, but each TCP/IP channel instance has a single conversation.
    32→
    33→Set a value of 1 on the Sharing Conversations attribute and select "on" in Share Single Conversation attribute of the mq-qm object in DataPower as shown in the following picture and a value of 1 on IBM WebSphere MQ SVRCONN setting.
    34→
    35→The Share Single Conversation attribute is only visible when "Sharing Conversations" is configured with value of "1" and then <RETURN> key is entered. For values greater than 1, the "Share Single Conversation" attribute is hidden in the mq-qm object.
    36→[/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21647231&aid=1] [/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21647231&aid=1]
    37→
    38→Case #3: The negotiated sharing conversations value is 2 or more - The channel supports IBM WebSphere MQ 7 and later release features and each TCP/IP channel instance supports 2 or more conversations.
    39→
    40→Set a value of 2 or more on the Sharing Conversations attribute of the mq-qm object in DataPower and on the MQ SVRCONN channel.
    41→
    42→On average, processing of messages from client applications is 15 percent slower when using SHARECNV(10) as compared to SHARECNV(0). Please refer to Performance Implications of Sharing [http://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSFKSJ_7.0.1/com.ibm.mq.csqzaf.doc/mi12240_.htm]
    43→Conversations on Client-connection Channels. [http://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSFKSJ_7.0.1/com.ibm.mq.csqzaf.doc/mi12240_.htm].
    44→
    45→Since DataPower uses a connection pool in processing MQ messages, there are no additional benefits of using sharing conversations with the mq-qm object. However, in situations when mixed message sizes are used by the same mq-qm object, using case #2 will benefit mq-qm object as it will use new buffer management feature of IBM WebSphere MQ Version 7 when making MQGET API call.
    46→
    47→When using a negotiated shared conversations value of 0 as in case #1, mq-qm object uses maximum message size as the buffer pool for the MQGET API call. However, when mixed message sizes are processed by the same MQ Front Side Handler (FSH), it requests buffer pool based on maximum message size configured in the mq-qm object. The use of fixed buffer pool for small and large messages can deplete MQ server's allocated buffer and contribute to unexpected termination of MQ SVRCONN channel instance and may terminate the queue manager. In such a situation, using a negotiated sharing conversations value of 1 as in case #2 will benefit DataPower mq-qm object as it will use IBM WebSphere MQ Version 7 Read Ahead feature and the new buffer management feature for MQGET API call. IBM WebSphere MQ V8 release provides enhanced performance for case #2, when the negotiated sharing conversations value is 1.
    48→
    49→For DataPower firmware releases 7.0.0.x, 7.1.0.x, 7.2.0.x and earlier, one should follow case #1 and use a negotiated sharing conversations value of 0. If you configure these firmware versions with case #2 or case #3, DataPower device may reload or hang due to connection instability and generate many MQ errors with Reason Code - 2009 and 2059.
    50→
    51→Cases #2 and #3 can be used in firmware releases 7.5.0.x, 7.5.1.x and later. We suggest to use a value of 10 or less in Sharing Conversations attribute of the mq-qm object and verify the configuration empirically to make sure that IBM WebSphere MQ server can sustain load from DataPower with the negotiated Sharing Conversations of 10.
    52→
    53→Note: In order to use sharing conversations, make sure you have applied APAR IV24821 [http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg1IV24821] ("Client C application process hangs after cancelling thread") to the IBM WebSphere MQ server. IV24821 is included in IBM WebSphere MQ V7.0.1.10 and later, IBM WebSphere MQ V7.1.0.3 and later, IBM WebSphere MQ V7.5.0.1 and later, and IBM WebSphere MQ V8.
    54→
    55→In order to identify the negotiated Sharing Conversations status, the following MQ commands are used in the distributed platform.
    56→
    57→runmqsc <qmgr>
    58→display chs(CHANNEL3) maxshcnv curshcnv
    59→
    60→display chs(CHANNEL3) maxshcnv curshcnv
    61→1 : display chs(CHANNEL3) maxshcnv curshcnv
    62→AMQ8417: Display Channel Status details.
    63→CHANNEL(CHANNEL3) CHLTYPE(SVRCONN)
    64→CONNAME(9.x1.x2.x3) CURRENT
    65→STATUS(RUNNING) SUBSTATE(RECEIVE)
    66→CURSHCNV(1) MAXSHCNV(1) <---- Negotiated Sharing Conversations value of 1
    67→AMQ8417: Display Channel Status details.
    68→CHANNEL(CHANNEL3) CHLTYPE(SVRCONN)
    69→CONNAME(9.y1.y2.y31) CURRENT
    70→STATUS(RUNNING) SUBSTATE(RECEIVE)
    71→CURSHCNV(0) MAXSHCNV(0) <---- Negotiated Sharing Conversations value of 0
    72→
    73→end
    74→--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    75→In order to identify the negotiated Sharing Conversations status, the following MQ commands are used in the z/OS System.
    76→
    77→connect to <qmgr>
    78→On z/OS system, options for issuing the commands are described at http://www-01.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSFKSJ_8.0.0/com.ibm.mq.ref.adm.doc/q085120_.htm [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSFKSJ_8.0.0/com.ibm.mq.ref.adm.doc/q085120_.htm].
    79→/+RTP8 DIS CHSTATUS(channel_name) MAXSHCNV CURSHCNV
    80→where "+RTP8" is the command prefix.

[TextBlock(text='根据知识库中的信息，我找到了关于 DataPower MQ 队列管理器中会话共享（conversation sharing）的详细说明：

## 何时使用会话共享

MQ 7.0 版本引入了会话共享（SHARECNV）功能，该功能指定每个 TCP/IP 通道实例可以共享的最大会话数。DataPower 可以配置此功能，因为它使用与队列管理器 SVRCONN 通道的客户端连接。

## DataPower 中的三种配置场景

**场景 #1：协商的会话共享值为 0**
- 在 DataPower mq-qm 对象中设置 Sharing Conversations 值为 0 或 1
- 通道运行在类似 WebSphere MQ V6 的模式，不使用以下功能：
  - 管理员停止静默
  - 心跳
  - 预读
  - 客户端异步消费

**场景 #2：协商的会话共享值为 1**
- 在 DataPower mq-qm 对象中设置 Sharing Conversations 值为 1
- 同时将 "Share Single Conversation" 属性设置为 "on"
- MQ SVRCONN 通道也设置为 1
- 支持 MQ V7 及更高版本的功能，但每个 TCP/IP 通道实例只有单个会话

**场景 #3：协商的会话共享值为 2 或更多**
- 在 DataPower mq-qm 对象和 MQ SVRCONN 通道上设置值为 2 或更多
- 支持 MQ V7 及更高版本的功能，每个通道实例支持多个会话

## DataPower 的特殊值

**重要特殊值：**
- DataPower mq-qm 对象中 Sharing Conversations 的默认值是 **0**（而 MQ SVRCONN 通道的默认值是 10）
- **在当前版本的 DataPower 固件中，Sharing Conversations 设置为 1 时，在与 MQ 服务器协商时会被视为 0**
- 会话共享值在 MQ 服务器和 DataPower 之间协商，较低的值生效

## 固件版本建议

- **DataPower 7.0.0.x、7.1.0.x、7.2.0.x 及更早版本**：应使用场景 #1（协商值为 0），否则可能导致设备重启或挂起
- **DataPower 7.5.0.x、7.5.1.x 及更高版本**：可以使用场景 #2 和 #3，建议使用 10 或更小的值

## 性能考虑

- 使用 SHARECNV(10) 比 SHARECNV(0) 平均慢约 15%
- 由于 DataPower 使用连接池处理 MQ 消息，使用会话共享通常没有额外好处
- 但在处理混合消息大小时，使用场景 #2 可以受益于 MQ V7 的新缓冲区管理功能

## 前提条件

使用会话共享前，确保 MQ 服务器已应用 APAR IV24821 补丁（包含在 MQ V7.0.1.10、V7.1.0.3、V7.5.0.1 及更高版本中）。')]

根据知识库中的信息，我找到了关于 DataPower MQ 队列管理器中会话共享（conversation sharing）的详细说明：

## 何时使用会话共享

MQ 7.0 版本引入了会话共享（SHARECNV）功能，该功能指定每个 TCP/IP 通道实例可以共享的最大会话数。DataPower 可以配置此功能，因为它使用与队列管理器 SVRCONN 通道的客户端连接。

## DataPower 中的三种配置场景

**场景 #1：协商的会话共享值为 0**
- 在 DataPower mq-qm 对象中设置 Sharing Conversations 值为 0 或 1
- 通道运行在类似 WebSphere MQ V6 的模式，不使用以下功能：
  - 管理员停止静默
  - 心跳
  - 预读
  - 客户端异步消费

**场景 #2：协商的会话共享值为 1**
- 在 DataPower mq-qm 对象中设置 Sharing Conversations 值为 1
- 同时将 "Share Single Conversation" 属性设置为 "on"
- MQ SVRCONN 通道也设置为 1
- 支持 MQ V7 及更高版本的功能，但每个 TCP/IP 通道实例只有单个会话

**场景 #3：协商的会话共享值为 2 或更多**
- 在 DataPower mq-qm 对象和 MQ SVRCONN 通道上设置值为 2 或更多
- 支持 MQ V7 及更高版本的功能，每个通道实例支持多个会话

## DataPower 的特殊值

**重要特殊值：**
- DataPower mq-qm 对象中 Sharing Conversations 的默认值是 **0**（而 MQ SVRCONN 通道的默认值是 10）
- **在当前版本的 DataPower 固件中，Sharing Conversations 设置为 1 时，在与 MQ 服务器协商时会被视为 0**
- 会话共享值在 MQ 服务器和 DataPower 之间协商，较低的值生效

## 固件版本建议

- **DataPower 7.0.0.x、7.1.0.x、7.2.0.x 及更早版本**：应使用场景 #1（协商值为 0），否则可能导致设备重启或挂起
- **DataPower 7.5.0.x、7.5.1.x 及更高版本**：可以使用场景 #2 和 #3，建议使用 10 或更小的值

## 性能考虑

- 使用 SHARECNV(10) 比 SHARECNV(0) 平均慢约 15%
- 由于 DataPower 使用连接池处理 MQ 消息，使用会话共享通常没有额外好处
- 但在处理混合消息大小时，使用场景 #2 可以受益于 MQ V7 的新缓冲区管理功能

## 前提条件

使用会话共享前，确保 MQ 服务器已应用 APAR IV24821 补丁（包含在 MQ V7.0.1.10、V7.1.0.3、V7.5.0.1 及更高版本中）。

query:
How can I export a private key from DataPower Gateway Appliance? 

How can I export a private key from DataPower Gateway appliance?
answer:
根据知识库检索结果，我找到了关于从 DataPower Gateway Appliance 导出私钥的详细信息。

## 如何从 DataPower Gateway Appliance 导出私钥

### 对于 HSM 启用的 DataPower 设备

HSM 启用的 DataPower 设备支持使用 **`crypto-export`** 命令导出私钥。但需要满足以下条件：

#### 必要条件：

1. **HSM 必须已初始化**，并且导出和导入机器上的 HSM 必须在同一个密钥共享域中

2. **私钥必须标记为可导出**
   - 在密钥生成时通过 `keygen` 命令的 `exportable` 选项设置
   - 如果密钥是在设备外部创建的（不是使用 keygen），则始终被视为可导出

3. **HSM 必须共享内部密钥包装密钥**（使用 `hsm-clone-kwk` 命令）
   - 密钥包装密钥是用于加密另一个密钥的密钥

#### 导出到同一设备 vs 不同设备：

**导出到同一设备：**
- 不需要担心 `hsm-clone-kwk`、red keys 或 `hsm-domain` 参数
- 因为导入时的密钥包装密钥与导出时相同

**导出到不同设备：**
需要执行以下步骤：

1. **初始化两个 HSM 到同一密钥共享域**
   - Security Level 2 模式：在 `hsm-reinit` 期间使用相同的 `hsm-domain` 参数
   - Security Level 3 模式：在 `hsm-reinit` 期间使用相同的 red PED key

2. **同步密钥包装密钥**
   - 使用 `hsm-clone-kwk` 命令，必须运行 4 次：
     - 在源 HSM 设备上运行一次
     - 在目标 HSM 设备上运行一次
     - 再次在源 HSM 设备上运行
     - 再次在目标 HSM 设备上运行
   - 每次运行都需要上一步的输出文件作为输入（通常使用 `copy` 命令手动移动）

3. **执行导出和导入**
   - 使用 `crypto-export` 导出私钥
   - 使用 `crypto-import` 导入私钥

### 对于非 HSM 设备

非 HSM 设备可以在密钥生成时立即导出密钥，但之后无法导出。

### 参考文档

更多信息请参考 IBM DataPower Info Center，搜索 "PIN entry device"。

---

**注意**：私钥的可导出性是不可变的，在密钥生成时确定，无法后续更改。

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_GGlufh70owZdsvPu3Uvsfv', content='{"result":"[\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": 5.9894,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"9741c198\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"9741c198-000\\",\\n    \\"chunk_index\\": 0,\\n    \\"path\\": \\"docs/ragbench-techqa/9741c198.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"TECHNOTE (FAQ)\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"TECHNOTE (FAQ)\\\\n\\\\nQUESTION\\\\n How do I export and import private keys between the same or different Hardware Security Module (HSM) enabled IBM WebSphere DataPower SOA Appliance?\\\\n\\\\nANSWER\\\\nHSM-enabled DataPower appliances support the export of private keys using the crypto-export command. For key export to work, various conditions must be met:\\\\n\\\\n * HSMs must be initialized and in the same key sharing domain on exporting and importing machines\\\\n * The private key in question must be marked exportable at keygen time (see keygen\'s exportable option)\\\\n * HSMs on exporting and importing machines must share internal key-wrapping keys (see hsm-clone-kwk command). A key-wrapping key is a key that encrypts another key.\\\\n\\\\nEach HSM has a special key inside of it, the key-wrapping key, that is used to encrypt exported private keys (and to decrypt imported private keys). If the goal is to restore exported keys to the same appliance, then you don\'t need to worry about hsm-clone-kwk, red keys, or the hsm-domain parameter. That is because the key-wrapping key at import time will already match the key-wrapping key at export time (since the HSM device is the same). If the goal is to move exported keys from one appliance to another one, then all of the steps in this section must be followed :-\\\\n\\\\nFirst, the two HSMs in question must be both be initialized and in the same key sharing domain. This means that they must both be initialized in the same mode (both in Security Level 2 or both in Security Level 3). In Security Level 2 mode, they must have used the same hsm-domain parameter during hsm-reinit (this parameter has a default value that is the same on all appliances). In Security Level 3 mode, they must have used the same red PED key during hsm-reinit (and the second initialization must not have overwritten the key value from the first initialization).\\\\n\\\\nSecond, the key to be exported must be exportable. The exportability of keys is immutable. It is determined at keygen time, and it is controlled by that command\'s exportable parameter. If a key was created outside of the appliance (not using keygen), then it is always considered exportable.\\\\n\\\\nFinally, before the crypto-export crypto-import sequence, the key-wrapping keys must be synchronized using the hsm-clone-kwk command. This command must be run four times: once on the source HSM appliance (with the key-wrapping key you are copying), once on the destination HSM appliance, once again on the source HSM appliance, and once again on the destination HSM appliance. Each time the command is run, it will need the output file from the previous step (as the input to the current step) which must be moved manually (usually with the copy command).\\\\n\\\\nOnce all of this has been done, then private keys may move from system to system with crypto-export and crypto-import.\\\\n\\\\nNote that the non-HSM appliance can export keys immediately at keygen time, but never at a later time.\\\\n\\\\nFor additional information refer to the online Info Center [http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/wsdatap/v3r8m2/index.jsp?topic=%2Fxi50%2Fwelcome.htm] and search for \\\\\\"PIN entry device\\\\\\".\\\\n\\\\nNote: You will need to sign into the documentation portal with your IBM Registration ID and password.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -1.5068,\\n [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg24039783]\\\\n\\\\nSUBSCRIBE\\\\nYou can track all active APARs for this component.\\\\n\\\\nAPAR STATUS\\\\n * CLOSED AS PROGRAM ERROR.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nERROR DESCRIPTION\\\\n *  Affected are customers sending HTTP GET requests to the\\\\n   multiprotocol gateway, web service proxy or web application\\\\n   firewall service.\\\\n\\\\n   With the present implementation, users may end up in a state\\\\n   with indefinite retries for HTTP GET requests as long as\\\\n   DataPower has at least one live persistent connection to the\\\\n   backend server. After timeout interval for active connection it\\\\n   will terminate the connection and retry using remaining\\\\n   persistent connections to the backend. (If a new connection is\\\\n   opened because of half-dead backend this can continue\\\\n   indefinitely or until the request is served).\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nLOCAL FIX\\\\n *  This behavior cannot be turned off however it can be mitigated.\\\\n   For some relief out of this, the admin can lower the Back\\\\n   Persistent Timeout and/or User Agent\'s default Timeout. This\\\\n   should result in less persistent connections to the backend and\\\\n   thus less possible timeout hops\\\\n\\\\n   Dropping the backend persistent connections option is also a\\\\n   possible workaround, but the consequences should be weighed\\\\n   carefully before making this decision. Not using persistent\\\\n   connections comes with a performance penalty, but it very much\\\\n   depends on the size/type of the transferred data and the\\\\n   speed/ping of the network.\\\\n\\\\n   SLM is also strongly encouraged to prevent the backend from\\\\n   getting more load than it can handle.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM SUMMARY\\\\n *  Affected are all customers using the Multi-Protocol Gateway,\\\\n   Web Service Proxy or Web Application Firewall with persistent\\\\n   connection to the backend side.\\\\n\\\\n   In case the backend server stops responding to HTTP GET\\\\n   requests while there are already some established TCP\\\\n   connections from the time the server worked OK, DataPower will\\\\n   automatically retry those GET requests after a timeout period.\\\\n   This will be retried until there are no established connections\\\\n   to the server.\\\\n\\\\n   During a high load window, these unwanted retries might\\\\n   eventually keep flooding an already congested backend,\\\\n   especially if it is still able to establish some new\\\\n   connections.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM CONCLUSION\\\\n *  Fix is available in 6.0.0.16, If the\\\\n   administrator tries to add the same Gateway node back in to\\\\n   the environment, the following error is displayed.\\\\n\\\\n   error message key:\\\\n   error message text: \\\\\\"An error ocurred while adding the gateway\\\\n   appliance \'\'${0}\'\' to the loadbalancer group used for internal\\\\n   traffic. The error was: ${1}: ${2}\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nLOCAL FIX\\\\n *  This issue can be resolved by manually removing the load\\\\n   balancer configuration from the Gateway node (DataPower\\\\n   appliance). To manually remove the load balancer, run the\\\\n   following CLI or GUI commands:  (where your\\\\n   DataPower appliance is configured to use the network interface\\\\n   \\\\\\"eth0\\\\\\", and the load balancer group is \\\\\\"123\\\\\\")  By\\\\n   using the CLI:  * ssh <datapower hostname> *\\\\n   enter your login credentials * co * int eth0 * no\\\\n   standby 123 * exit * write mem  By using the\\\\n   DataPower user interface:  Open the Network and\\\\n   Interface folders in the navigation tree. * Click \\\\\\"Ethernet\\\\n   Interface\\\\\\". * Click the relevant interface row in the\\\\n   table. * Select the \\\\\\"Standby Control\\\\\\" tab. * Click X\\\\n   on the relevant table row to delete the load balancing\\\\n   group. * Click \\\\\\"Apply\\\\\\". * Click \\\\\\"Save Config\\\\\\" in the\\\\n   page header.  Also, to prevent any port conflicts,\\\\n   remove all IBM API Management domains from the Gateway node\\\\n   (DataPower appliance) too. The IBM API Management related\\\\n   domains have the format of \\\\\\"APIMgmt_<10 alphanumeric\\\\n   characters>\\\\\\". Otherwise, adding the Gateway node appears to\\\\n   complete successfully but when APIs that are created by using\\\\n   the recreated Management node are accessed, you see 404 errors.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM SUMMARY\\\\n *  When a Gateway node is removed from an IBM API Management\\\\n   environment, there are some scenarios where the configuration of\\\\n   the Gateway node might not be successfully cleaned. If the\\\\n   administrator tries to add the same Gateway node back in to\\\\n   the environment, an error is displayed.\\\\n\\\\n   In particular, this occurs if the Management node(s) of the\\\\n   environment is deleted and recreated without first removing\\\\n   the Gateway node (the Gateway node was never actually removed\\\\n   from the environment).\\\\n\\\\n   The external symptom of this problem is the error message that\\\\n   is displayed when adding the gateway node.\\\\n\\\\n   error message key: FAILURE_ADDING_APICALL_LOADBALANCER\\\\n   error message text: \\\\\\"An error ocurred while adding the gateway\\\\n   appliance \'\'${0}\'\' to the loadbalancer group used for internal\\\\n   traffic. The error was: ${1}: ${2}\\\\\\"\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM CONCLUSION\\\\n *  The IBM API Management code has been updated to resolve this\\\\n   error.\\\\n\\\\n   The update has been SECURITY BULLETIN\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"CVE-2014-8730 SECURITY BULLETIN\\\\n\\\\nSUMMARY\\\\n IBM Security Access Manager version 8.0.0.5 for DataPower is affected by a TLS padding vulnerability, which could allow a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information.\\\\n\\\\nVULNERABILITY DETAILS\\\\nThe following vulnerability affects IBM Security Access Manager version 8.0.0.5 for DataPower.\\\\nCVEID: CVE-2014-8730 [http://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2014-8730]\\\\n\\\\nDESCRIPTION: IBM Security Access Manager for DataPower could allow a remote attacker to obtain sensitive information, caused by the failure to check the contents of the padding bytes when using CBC cipher suites of some TLS implementations. A remote user with the ability to conduct a man-in-the-middle attack could exploit this vulnerability via a POODLE (Padding Oracle On Downgraded Legacy Encryption) like attack to decrypt sensitive information and calculate the plaintext of secure connections.\\\\n\\\\nCVSS Base Score: 4.3\\\\nCVSS Temporal Score: See http://xforce.iss.net/xforce/xfdb/99216 [http://xforce.iss.net/xforce/xfdb/99216] for the current score\\\\nCVSS Environmental Score*: Undefined\\\\nCVSS Vector: (AV:N/AC:M/Au:N/C:P/I:N/A:N)\\\\n\\\\nAFFECTED PRODUCTS AND VERSIONS\\\\nIBM Security Access Manager version 8.0.0.5 for DataPower in all WebSphere DataPower Gateway appliances version 7.1.0.\\\\n\\\\nREMEDIATION/FIXES\\\\nNone\\\\n\\\\nWORKAROUNDS AND MITIGATIONS\\\\nThe following steps describe how to mitigate this vulnerability for the affected releases. You should verify applying this configuration change does not cause any compatibility issues.\\\\n\\\\nMitigation for IBM Security Access Manager for DataPower 8.0.0.5\\\\n\\\\n 1. Select Objects > Security Access Manager > Access Manager Reverse Proxy from the WebGUI navigation panel.\\\\n 2. Select the Reverse Proxy instance.\\\\n 3. Select the Manage Files tab and then the Edit button for the Configuration File property.\\\\n 4. In the [ssl] stanza, add the bold lines below to the following two sections.\\\\n    # Specify any additional GSKit attributes which should be used when\\\\n    # initializing an SSL connection with the client. A complete list of\\\\n    # the available attributes is included in the GSKit SSL API\\\\n    # documentation.\\\\n    #\\\\n    # The configuration entry may be specified multiple times, one for each\\\\n    # GSKit attribute. The entry should be of the format:\\\\n    # gsk-attr-name = <type>:<id>:<value>\\\\n    #\\\\n    # - where <type> is one of \'enum\', \'string\', \'number\'\\\\n    # and <id> corresponds to the identity associated with a GSKit attribute\\\\n    # (e.g., GSK_HTTP_PROXY_SERVER_NAME = 225)\\\\n    #\\\\n    # An example configuration could be:\\\\n    # gsk-attr-name = string:225:proxy.ibm.com\\\\n\\\\n    gsk-attr-name = enum:471:1\\\\n\\\\n    # Specify any additional GSKit attributes which should be used when\\\\n    # initializing an SSL connection with a junctioned server. A complete\\\\n    # list of the available attributes is included in the GSKit SSL API\\\\n    # documentation.\\\\n    #\\\\n    # The configuration entry may be specified multiple times, one for each\\\\n    # GSKit attribute. The entry should be of the format:\\\\n    # jct-gsk-attr-name = <type>:<id>:<value>\\\\n    #\\\\n    # - where <type> is one of \'enum\', \'string\', \'number\'\\\\n    # and <id> corresponds to the identity associated with a GSKit attribute\\\\n    # (e.g., GSK_HTTP_PROXY_SERVER_NAME = 225)\\\\n    #\\\\n    # An example configuration could be:\\\\n    # jct-gsk-attr-name = string:225:proxy.ibm.com\\\\n\\\\n    jct-gsk-attr-name = enum:471:1\\\\n 5. Click Apply to deploy the changes.\\\\n\\\\nGET NOTIFIED ABOUT FUTURE SECURITY BULLETINS\\\\n Subscribe to My Notifications [ http://www-01.ibm.com/software/support/einfo.html] to be notified of important product support alerts like this.\\\\n\\\\nREFERENCES\\\\nComplete CVSS v2 Guide [http://www.first.org/cvss/v2/guide]\\\\nOn-line Calculator v2 [http://nvd.nist.gov/CVSS-v2-Calculator] RELATED INFORMATION\\\\nIBM Secure Engineering Web Portal [http://www.ibm.com/security/secure-engineering/bulletins.html]\\\\nIBM Product Security Incident Response Blog [http://www.ibm.com/blogs/PSIRT] Security Access Manager for Web Security Bulletin (CVE-2014-8730) [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21692802] ACKNOWLEDGEMENT\\\\nNone\\\\n\\\\n*The CVSS Environment Score is customer environment specific and will ultimately impact the Overall CVSS Score. Customers can evaluate the impact of this vulnerability in their environments by accessing the links in the Reference section of this Security Bulletin.\\\\n\\\\nDISCLAIMER\\\\nAccording to the Forum of Incident Response and Security Teams (FIRST), the Common Vulnerability Scoring System (CVSS) is an \\\\\\"industry open standard designed to convey vulnerability severity and help to determine urgency and priority of response.\\\\\\" IBM PROVIDES THE CVSS SCORES \\\\\\"AS IS\\\\\\" WITHOUT WARRANTY OF ANY KIND, INCLUDING THE IMPLIED WARRANTIES OF MERCHANTABILITY AND FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. CUSTOMERS ARE RESPONSIBLE FOR ASSESSING THE IMPACT OF ANY ACTUAL OR POTENTIAL SECURITY VULNERABILITY.\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -1.3988,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"b35766e5\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"b35766e5-000\\",\\n    \\"chunk_index\\": 0,\\n    \\"path\\": \\"docs/ragbench-techqa/b35766e5.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"datapower; routing; route; default; static; gateway; default gateway; static rou\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"datapower; routing; route; default; static; gateway; default gateway; static route TECHNOTE (TROUBLESHOOTING)\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM(ABSTRACT)\\\\n The default route and static routes on the DataPower appliance have different functionality and behavior.\\\\n\\\\nRESOLVING THE PROBLEM\\\\nA static route forces the DataPower appliance to use a specific interface and a specific set of network hops to access a given set of destinations. The \\\\\\"default route\\\\\\" is created by setting the Default Gateway of an interface on a DataPower appliance.\\\\n\\\\nA default route will be used if a known route does not exist for a given destination address. If multiple default routes are configured, the appliance will randomly pick which interface to use for outbound traffic if a more specific route cannot be found.\\\\n\\\\nIf you want your network traffic to follow a specific route, set a static route and NOT rely on the default gateway. As a general rule, the management interface should not have the default gateway set, as you generally want to restrict the connections that can be made through that interface.\\\\n\\\\nA general recommendation is to set specific static routes and only ONE default gateway that will catch all traffic not being directed by the static routes.\\\\n\\\\nConsider the following example after running this command from the CLI:\\\\n\\\\nxs40# show route\\\\n\\\\ndestination interface gateway metric 0.0.0.0/0 eth0 167.91.8.1 0 0.0.0.0/0 eth1 167.91.7.1 0 0.0.0.0/0 mgt0 10.238.77.1 0 10.238.77.0/24 mgt0 [/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21249208&aid=1] 0 167.81.18.0/23 eth0 [/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21249208&aid=1] 0 167.81.18.0/23 eth1 [/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21249208&aid=1] 0\\\\n\\\\nThe output above shows that three default gateways were configured on eth0, eth1, and mgt0 which causes three \\\\\\"default\\\\\\" route to be generated (0.0.0.0/0). If the destination address of your service is 166.84.23.4, the device will randomly choose any one of the default routes as no specific route is configured. If, for example, the gateway picked is 10.238.77.1 and the gateway does not know how to route to the needed backend server ip address, this will cause unexpected connection failures. In the case of such failure, a reboot of the device will lead to a different route to be randomly picked, thus temporarily resolving until the next failure.\\\\n\\\\nFirmware 3.7.2 and later\\\\n\\\\nInstructions for setting the default gateway and for setting a static route can be found in the \\\\\\"Managing the appliance\\\\\\" section of the Administrators Guide. The command line commands are ip default-gateway and ip route respectively, and more information is available in the CLI Reference Guide.\\\\n\\\\nFirmware earlier than 3.7.2\\\\n\\\\nInstructions for setting the default gateway and static routes can be found in the \\\\\\"Ethernet Interface\\\\\\" appendix of the WebGUI Guide. The command line commands are ip default-gateway and ip route respectively, and more information is available in the CLI Reference Guide.\\\\n\\\\nTo access product documentation, see these instructions. [http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=2362&uid=swg21377654]\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nCross reference information Segment Product Component Platform Version Edition Business Integration WebSphere DataPower Integration Appliance XI50 Not Applicable Firmware 3.8.2, 3.8.1, 3.8, 3.7.3 Business Integration WebSphere DataPower B2B Appliance XB60 Not Applicable Firmware 3.7.3 Business Integration WebSphere DataPower Low Latency Appliance XM70 Not Applicable Firmware 3.7.3 Business Integration WebSphere DataPower XML Security Gateway XS40 Not Applicable Firmware 3.8.2, 3.8.1, 3.8, 3.7.3 Business Integration WebSphere DataPower XML Accelerator XA35 Not Applicable Firmware 3.8.2, 3.8.1, 3.8, 3.7.3\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -1.9243,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"d3625f63\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"d3625f63-000\\",\\n    \\"chunk_index\\": 0,\\n    \\"path\\": \\"docs/ragbench-techqa/d3625f63.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"TECHNOTE (FAQ)\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"TECHNOTE (FAQ)\\\\n\\\\nQUESTION\\\\n How do I add the Data Integration Module to an IBM WebSphere DataPower Service Gateway XG45 appliance?\\\\n\\\\nThe following document provides assistance on upgrading a DataPower Service Gateway XG45 appliance to add the Data Integration Module.\\\\n\\\\nANSWER\\\\nTo add the Data Integration Module:\\\\n\\\\n * The appliance must be a DataPower Service Gateway XG45 running firmware 4.0.2.0 or later.\\\\n * You purchased the Data Integration Module and received a letter that contains the Controlled Access Key to download the firmware image.\\\\n\\\\nPart 1: Accessing the Web site that contains the firmware image.\\\\nUsing your IBM account and Controlled Access Key, access the Web site to download the firmware image that contains the Data Integration Module.\\\\n 1. Identify the serial number for your appliance  * From the WebGUI, click Status -> System -> Version Information.\\\\n     * From the command line, issue the show version command.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n 2. Follow the instructions in the Authorized Feature Download letter to access the WebSphere DataPower Registered Downloads portal [http://www.ibm.com/services/forms/preLogin.do?lang=en_US&source=swg-datapowerapps].\\\\n 3. Sign in using your IBM user ID and password. Register, if you do not have an ID.\\\\n 4. Enter the Controlled Access Key in the letter to access the web page containing the firmware images. Ensure that the first 7-characters of the Controlled Access Key in the letter matches the serial number for the appliance that you obtained in step 1.\\\\n\\\\nYou are now ready to continue to Part 2 to download the firmware image.\\\\n\\\\nPart 2: Downloading the firmware image.\\\\n 1. Download the image.\\\\n 2. Do not transfer the image to the appliance at this time. You will install the image in Part 4: Installing the firmware image.\\\\n\\\\nPart 3: Preparing for the firmware upgrade.\\\\nReview the installation instructions and prepare your appliance for the firmware upgrade.\\\\n 1. Read the upgrade documentation in the version-specific DataPower information center. Instructions for accessing the correct information center is in the [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=2362&uid=swg21377654]IBM WebSphere DataPower Product Documentation Portal [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=2362&uid=swg21377654] technical flash. The steps in this flash provide additional information to use with the upgrade documentation in the information center.\\\\n 2. Save the current configuration.  * From the WebGUI, click Save Config.\\\\n     * From the command line, issue the write memory command.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n 3. Create a backup of the entire system, and store the configuration in a safe location off of the appliance.\\\\n 4. Confirm that you have a working admin account and a back up privileged account that can change the password for the admin account, if needed.\\\\n 5. Make sure that the passwords for both accounts were recently changed.\\\\n\\\\nPart 4: Installing the license image.\\\\nInstall the license image. Each license image uses the serial number of the appliance as the key.\\\\n 1. Remove appliance from production.\\\\n 2. Following the instructions upgrade documentation in the information center:  * Remove extraneous files\\\\n     * Reboot the appliance to release temporary storage\\\\n     * Transfer the firmware image to the appliance\\\\n     * Install the firmware image\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n 3. Verify that the appliance has the Data Integration Module.  * From the WebGUI, click Status -> System -> Device Features. The list includes:  * Binary processing support\\\\n        * PKCS #7 and S/MIME support\\\\n        * SQL-ODBC support\\\\n        * Database Connectivity Option support\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n     * From the command line, issue the show features command. The list includes:  * DataGlue\\\\n        * PKCS7-SMIME\\\\n        * SQL-ODBC\\\\n        * DCO\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nPart 5: Installing the firmware image.\\\\nInstall the firmware image. XG45 firmware images selectively install only the features licensed for the appliance. In order to make the Data Integration Module features available, the firmware must be upgrade after installing the license image.\\\\n 1. Download the firmware image for your appliance model and licenses from FixCentral\\\\n 2. Upgrade the appliance firmware following the upgrade documentation in the information center\\\\n 3. Repeat part 4 step 3 and ensure all of the licenses are both enabled and available.\\\\n\\\\nIf the installation is successful and the list does not include the features for the Data Integration Module, the most likely reason is that the firmware image was for a different appliance. Each firmware image to add the Data Integration Module uses the serial number of the appliance as the key. If you install a downloaded image to a different appliance, you will notice that the firmware is upgraded to that firmware level and that the features for the Data Integration Module are not available.\\\\n\\\\nIf you accessed the download site using the Controlled Access Key and installed the downloaded image to the appliance with the matching serial number and the feature list does not include the features for the Data Integration Module, contact IBM Support [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21236322].\\\\n\\\\nContacting IBM Support\\\\nWhen reporting the problem to IBM Support, the representative will need your Controlled Access Key in addition to the standard information to include. Go to Contacting IBM WebSphere DataPower Appliances Support [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21236322].\\"\\n  },\\n  {\\n    \\"score\\": -2.2673,\\n    \\"doc_id\\": \\"6f2c6c6e\\",\\n    \\"chunk_id\\": \\"6f2c6c6e-000\\",\\n    \\"chunk_index\\": 0,\\n    \\"path\\": \\"docs/ragbench-techqa/6f2c6c6e.md\\",\\n    \\"title\\": \\"SUBSCRIBE\\",\\n    \\"section_path\\": \\"\\",\\n    \\"confidence\\": \\"medium\\",\\n    \\"text\\": \\"SUBSCRIBE\\\\nYou can track all active APARs for this component.\\\\n\\\\nAPAR STATUS\\\\n * CLOSED AS PROGRAM ERROR.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nERROR DESCRIPTION\\\\n *  When assimilating one appliance into another to form a\\\\n   two-appliance collective, the assimilation task might fail. [TextBlock(text='根据知识库检索结果，我找到了关于从 DataPower Gateway Appliance 导出私钥的详细信息。

## 如何从 DataPower Gateway Appliance 导出私钥

### 对于 HSM 启用的 DataPower 设备

HSM 启用的 DataPower 设备支持使用 **`crypto-export`** 命令导出私钥。但需要满足以下条件：

#### 必要条件：

1. **HSM 必须已初始化**，并且导出和导入机器上的 HSM 必须在同一个密钥共享域中

2. **私钥必须标记为可导出**
   - 在密钥生成时通过 `keygen` 命令的 `exportable` 选项设置
   - 如果密钥是在设备外部创建的（不是使用 keygen），则始终被视为可导出

3. **HSM 必须共享内部密钥包装密钥**（使用 `hsm-clone-kwk` 命令）
   - 密钥包装密钥是用于加密另一个密钥的密钥

#### 导出到同一设备 vs 不同设备：

**导出到同一设备：**
- 不需要担心 `hsm-clone-kwk`、red keys 或 `hsm-domain` 参数
- 因为导入时的密钥包装密钥与导出时相同

**导出到不同设备：**
需要执行以下步骤：

1. **初始化两个 HSM 到同一密钥共享域**
   - Security Level 2 模式：在 `hsm-reinit` 期间使用相同的 `hsm-domain` 参数
   - Security Level 3 模式：在 `hsm-reinit` 期间使用相同的 red PED key

2. **同步密钥包装密钥**
   - 使用 `hsm-clone-kwk` 命令，必须运行 4 次：
     - 在源 HSM 设备上运行一次
     - 在目标 HSM 设备上运行一次
     - 再次在源 HSM 设备上运行
     - 再次在目标 HSM 设备上运行
   - 每次运行都需要上一步的输出文件作为输入（通常使用 `copy` 命令手动移动）

3. **执行导出和导入**
   - 使用 `crypto-export` 导出私钥
   - 使用 `crypto-import` 导入私钥

### 对于非 HSM 设备

非 HSM 设备可以在密钥生成时立即导出密钥，但之后无法导出。

### 参考文档

更多信息请参考 IBM DataPower Info Center，搜索 "PIN entry device"。

---

**注意**：私钥的可导出性是不可变的，在密钥生成时确定，无法后续更改。')]

根据知识库检索结果，我找到了关于从 DataPower Gateway Appliance 导出私钥的详细信息。

## 如何从 DataPower Gateway Appliance 导出私钥

### 对于 HSM 启用的 DataPower 设备

HSM 启用的 DataPower 设备支持使用 **`crypto-export`** 命令导出私钥。但需要满足以下条件：

#### 必要条件：

1. **HSM 必须已初始化**，并且导出和导入机器上的 HSM 必须在同一个密钥共享域中

2. **私钥必须标记为可导出**
   - 在密钥生成时通过 `keygen` 命令的 `exportable` 选项设置
   - 如果密钥是在设备外部创建的（不是使用 keygen），则始终被视为可导出

3. **HSM 必须共享内部密钥包装密钥**（使用 `hsm-clone-kwk` 命令）
   - 密钥包装密钥是用于加密另一个密钥的密钥

#### 导出到同一设备 vs 不同设备：

**导出到同一设备：**
- 不需要担心 `hsm-clone-kwk`、red keys 或 `hsm-domain` 参数
- 因为导入时的密钥包装密钥与导出时相同

**导出到不同设备：**
需要执行以下步骤：

1. **初始化两个 HSM 到同一密钥共享域**
   - Security Level 2 模式：在 `hsm-reinit` 期间使用相同的 `hsm-domain` 参数
   - Security Level 3 模式：在 `hsm-reinit` 期间使用相同的 red PED key

2. **同步密钥包装密钥**
   - 使用 `hsm-clone-kwk` 命令，必须运行 4 次：
     - 在源 HSM 设备上运行一次
     - 在目标 HSM 设备上运行一次
     - 再次在源 HSM 设备上运行
     - 再次在目标 HSM 设备上运行
   - 每次运行都需要上一步的输出文件作为输入（通常使用 `copy` 命令手动移动）

3. **执行导出和导入**
   - 使用 `crypto-export` 导出私钥
   - 使用 `crypto-import` 导入私钥

### 对于非 HSM 设备

非 HSM 设备可以在密钥生成时立即导出密钥，但之后无法导出。

### 参考文档

更多信息请参考 IBM DataPower Info Center，搜索 "PIN entry device"。

---

**注意**：私钥的可导出性是不可变的，在密钥生成时确定，无法后续更改。

query:
How to resolve the StaleConnectionException in WebSphere Application Server? I see this exception in WebSphere Application Server J2c and RRA traces:

WSRdbManagedC > preTestConnection Entry WSRdbManagedConnectionImpl@51a507f2 query: SELECT 1 FROM DUAL WSRdbManagedC 3 Exception java.sql.SQLException: ORA-02396: exceeded maximum idle time, please connect again DSRA0010E: SQL State = 61000, Error Code = 2,396 at oracle.jdbc.driver.T4CTTIoer.processError(T4CTTIoer.java:440) at 
...
Entry java.sql.SQLException: ORA-01012: not logged on ..... OracleDataSto < findMappingClass return Exit class com.ibm.websphere.ce.cm.StaleConnectionException
answer:
Based on my search of the knowledge base, I don't have a specific document that directly addresses your exact StaleConnectionException scenario with Oracle errors ORA-02396 and ORA-01012. However, I can provide you with the standard resolution approach for this type of issue based on WebSphere Application Server connection pool management principles:

## How to Resolve StaleConnectionException in WebSphere Application Server

### Understanding the Problem

The errors you're seeing indicate:
- **ORA-02396**: "exceeded maximum idle time, please connect again" - Oracle has terminated the connection due to idle timeout
- **ORA-01012**: "not logged on" - The connection is no longer valid
- **StaleConnectionException**: WebSphere detected the connection is stale during preTestConnection validation

This happens when connections in the WebSphere connection pool remain idle longer than Oracle's `IDLE_TIME` profile parameter allows, causing Oracle to terminate them server-side while WebSphere still considers them valid.

### Resolution Steps

**1. Enable Connection Testing in WebSphere Data Source**

Configure your data source to test connections before use:

- Navigate to: **Resources > JDBC > Data sources > [Your DataSource] > Connection pool properties**
- Set **Pretest connections** = `true` (enabled)
- This ensures WebSphere validates connections before handing them to applications

**2. Adjust Connection Pool Timeouts**

Match WebSphere timeouts to Oracle's settings:

- **Connection timeout**: Set lower than Oracle's `IDLE_TIME`
- **Reap time**: Enable connection reaping (e.g., 180 seconds)
- **Unused timeout**: Set to remove idle connections (e.g., 1800 seconds)
- **Aged timeout**: Set to refresh old connections (e.g., 3600 seconds)

**3. Configure Oracle Profile Settings**

Check and adjust Oracle's idle timeout:

```sql
-- Check current IDLE_TIME setting
SELECT resource_name, limit 
FROM dba_profiles 
WHERE profile = 'DEFAULT' 
AND resource_name = 'IDLE_TIME';

-- Increase IDLE_TIME if needed (value in minutes, UNLIMITED for no limit)
ALTER PROFILE DEFAULT LIMIT IDLE_TIME UNLIMITED;
```

**4. Set Test Connection Interval**

- In the data source custom properties, add:
  - **preTestSQLString** = `SELECT 1 FROM DUAL`
  - This provides a lightweight query for connection validation

**5. Enable Purge Policy**

- Set **Purge policy** = `EntirePool` or `FailingConnectionOnly`
- This determines how WebSphere handles stale connections when detected

### Additional Recommendations

- Review WebSphere logs for the frequency of these exceptions
- Monitor Oracle's `V$SESSION` to see connection lifecycle
- Consider reducing connection pool size if you have many idle connections
- Ensure your application properly closes connections after use

### Configuration Example

In the WebSphere Admin Console:
```
Data Source > Connection Pool Properties:
- Minimum connections: 5
- Maximum connections: 50
- Connection timeout: 30 seconds
- Reap time: 180 seconds
- Unused timeout: 1800 seconds
- Aged timeout: 3600 seconds
- Purge policy: EntirePool

Data Source > Custom Properties:
- preTestSQLString = SELECT 1 FROM DUAL
- validateConnection = true
```

The key is ensuring WebSphere detects and removes stale connections before they're used by applications, and aligning the timeout settings between WebSphere and Oracle to prevent the mismatch that causes these exceptions.

ERROR.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nERROR DESCRIPTION\\\\n *  WebSphere MQ Classes for Java/JMS V7.0.1.5 (or later): Failure\\\\n   Data Capture (FDC) files\\\\n   with Probe\\\\n   ID JO076001 and JO205001 are generated following a remote\\\\n   connection to a Queue Manager that has conversation sharing\\\\n   disabled:\\\\n\\\\n   | Probe Id     :- JO076001\\\\n   | Component    :- RemoteFAP.MQOPEN(Hconn,MQOD,int,Phobj,Pi\\\\n   | Probe Type   :- INCORROUT\\\\n   | Comment1     :- MQOPEN reply expected\\\\n\\\\n   | Probe Id     :- JO205001\\\\n   | Component    :- RemoteConnection.removeHconn(RemoteTls,R\\\\n   | Probe Type   :- INCORROUT\\\\n   | Comment1     :- Hconn is not associated with this connection\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nLOCAL FIX\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM SUMMARY\\\\n *  ****************************************************************\\\\n   USERS AFFECTED:\\\\n   This issue affects users of the WebSphere MQ V7.0.1.5 Classes\\\\n   for Java/JMS (or later) who have established a remote connection\\\\n   to a Queue Manager via a channel that has Conversation Sharing\\\\n   disabled (SHARECNV=0 or SHARECNV=1).\\\\n\\\\n   This includes users of:\\\\n\\\\n   - The WebSphere MQ V7.0.1 Classes for JMS\\\\n   - The WebSphere MQ V7.0.1 Resource Adapter.\\\\n   - The WebSphere Application Server V7.0 and V8.0 WebSphere MQ\\\\n   messaging provider.\\\\n   - The WebSphere Application Server V6.1 WebSphere MQ messaging\\\\n   provider who have configured the WebSphere variable\\\\n   MQ_INSTALL_ROOT to point to a WebSphere MQ V7.0.1 installation.\\\\n\\\\n   Platforms affected:\\\\n   All Distributed (iSeries, all Unix and Windows)\\\\n   ****************************************************************\\\\n   PROBLEM SUMMARY:\\\\n   By default in the WebSphere MQ Classes for Java/JMS,\\\\n   conversation\\\\n   sharing is enabled and set to 10 on the client side. The client\\\\n   only discovers that Conversation Sharing is disabled following\\\\n   negotiation with a Queue Manager on the completion of a\\\\n   connection over a Channel that has SHARECNV=0 or SHARECNV=1.\\\\n\\\\n   When a WebSphere MQ Classes for Java/JMS application requests a\\\\n   remote connection to a Queue Manager the client first attempts\\\\n   to find an already established TCP/IP connection which can be\\\\n   shared. As part of this process the list of known TCP/IP\\\\n   connections are matched for their suitability, this list\\\\n   includes connections which are in the process of being\\\\n   established (MQCONN reply not received from the Queue Manager).\\\\n\\\\n   When a WebSphere MQ Classes for Java/JMS application requested a\\\\n   remote connection it was matched for sharing with a connection\\\\n   that was still in the process of being established. The\\\\n   WebSphere MQ Client waited for the connection to complete and\\\\n   due to a small timing window began incorrectly sharing the\\\\n   connection without confirming the connection\'s suitability. If\\\\n   the connection\'s suitability had been checked then the\\\\n   connection\\\\n   would have been marked unsuitable due to the Negotiated Channel\\\\n   specifying that Conversation Sharing was disabled (SHARECNV=0 or\\\\n   SHARECNV=1).\\\\n   As the connection (which did not support conversation sharing)\\\\n   was now shared by two threads, packets destined for one thread\\\\n   were erroneously received by the other, this led to the client\\\\n   being in an inconsistent state and the two FDCs being generated.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM CONCLUSION\\\\n *  The WebSphere MQ Classes for Java/JMS have been modified to\\\\n   correctly restrict conversation sharing when using a connection\\\\n   that does not support conversation sharing (SHARECNV=0 or\\\\n   SHARECNV=1).\\\\n\\\\n   ---------------------------------------------------------------\\\\n   The fix is targeted for delivery in the following PTFs:\\\\n\\\\n   Version    Maintenance Level\\\\n   v7.0       7.0.1.12\\\\n\\\\n   The latest available maintenance can be obtained from\\\\n   \'WebSphere MQ Recommended Fixes\'\\\\n   http://www-1.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=171&uid=swg27006037 ERROR.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nERROR DESCRIPTION\\\\n *  In SAML Web SSO, when the redirect target is null,\\\\n   \\\\\\"INTERNAL ERROR: Please contact your support.\\\\\\" is displayed\\\\n   in the browser.  There is no information in the FFDC or\\\\n   SystemOut.log for problem diagnosis.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nLOCAL FIX\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM SUMMARY\\\\n *  ****************************************************************\\\\n   * USERS AFFECTED:  IBM WebSphere Application Server users of   *\\\\n   *                  SAML Web SSO                                *\\\\n   ****************************************************************\\\\n   * PROBLEM DESCRIPTION: Additional diagnostics are required     *\\\\n   *                      when the SAML Web SSO redirect URL is   *\\\\n   *                      null                                    *\\\\n   ****************************************************************\\\\n   * RECOMMENDATION:  Install a fix pack that contains this       *\\\\n   *                  APAR.                                       *\\\\n   ****************************************************************\\\\n   In SAML Web SSO, when the redirect target is null, the runtime\\\\n   sets the redirect target to NO_TARGET.  This results in\\\\n   \\\\\\"INTERNAL ERROR: Please contact your support.\\\\\\" being displayed\\\\n   in the browser.\\\\n   .\\\\n   There should be some indication in the SystemOut.log that this\\\\n   condition has happened so that the administrator can attempt\\\\n   to address the issue.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM CONCLUSION\\\\n *  The SAML Web SSO TAI is updated to redirect to the configured\\\\n   error page when the redirect target is null.\\\\n   .\\\\n   When the redirect target is null, the following error message\\\\n   will appear in the SystemOut.log file:\\\\n   .\\\\n   CWSML7035E: The SAML Web Single Sign-on (SSO) Trust\\\\n   Association Interceptor (TAI) is unable to determine a\\\\n   redirect target URL. The redirect URL can come from the\\\\n   sso_<id>.sp.targetUrl SAML TAI custom property, the RelayState\\\\n   parameter in the SAMLResponse or the WasSamlSpReqUrl cookie.\\\\n   If you do not intend to have a value for the\\\\n   sso_<id>.sp.targetUrl SAML TAI custom property or have your\\\\n   IdP send a RelayState parameter in the SAMLResponse, then\\\\n   check earlier in the log to see if you have a CWSML7036W\\\\n   warning that indicates that the request URL host name is not\\\\n   the same as the ACS URL host name. If you see that warning,\\\\n   then that condition must be corrected to fix this error. The\\\\n   value for the relayState parameter on the SAMLResponse is [{0}].\\\\n   .\\\\n   EXPLANATION: The SAML Web SSO TAI cannot find a redirect URL\\\\n   for the current request.  The redirect URL can come from three\\\\n   places: 1) the sso_<id>.sp.targetUrl SAML TAI custom property,\\\\n   2) the RelayState parameter in the SAMLResponse and 3) the\\\\n   WasSamlSpReqUrl cookie. At least one of these three things\\\\n   must be present in order for the SAML TAI to be able to\\\\n   determine the redirect URL. In this case, none of these three\\\\n   things are present, therefore, the SAML TAI can not determine\\\\n   the redirect URL. Note that the SAML TAI may have set a\\\\n   WasSamlSpReqUrl cookie earlier in the process, but the browser\\\\n   did not make the cookie available to the SAML TAI. Also, the\\\\n   RelayState parameter must be a URL that uses the http or https\\\\n   protocol.\\\\n   .\\\\n   USER ACTION: Ensure at least one of the following is true: 1)\\\\n   the sso_<id>.sp.targetUrl SAML TAI custom property is\\\\n   configured for the current SP, 2) the IdP sets the RelayState\\\\n   parameter on the SAMLResponse with a valid URL that uses the\\\\n   http or https protocol or 3) the WasSamlSpReqUrl cookie is\\\\n   made available to the SAML TAI. In order for the\\\\n   WasSamlSpReqUrl to be available to the SAML TAI, the original\\\\n   request URL must have the same host name as the ACS URL that\\\\n   is configured on the sso_<id>.sp.acsUrl TAI custom property.\\\\n   .\\\\n   .\\\\n   The SAML TAI is also updated to check for duplicate acsUrl\\\\n   entries at load time.  If any are found, the following warning\\\\n   will be emitted:\\\\n   .\\\\n   CWSML7038W: The SAML Web Single Single Sign-on (SSO) Trust\\\\n   Association Interceptor (TAI) has two assertion consumer\\\\n   service URL custom properties configured that have the same\\\\n   URL path: [{0}] and [{1}].  This condition can cause\\\\n   unexpected behavior at run time.  To prevent further issues,\\\\n   all text after <hostname>:<port> must be unique for each\\\\n   [sso_<id>.sp.acsUrl] custom property value.\\\\n   .\\\\n   EXPLANATION: The value for each SAML [sso_<id>.sp.acsUrl]\\\\n   custom property must have a unique URL path.  A URL path does\\\\n   not include the protocol and <hostname>:<port> parts of a URL\\\\n   string.  For example, although the URL strings for\\\\n   https://somewhere.ibm.com/samlsps/hello/app and\\\\n   https://elsewhere.ibm.com/samlsps/hello/app are different, the\\\\n   URL paths are the same.  If two acsUrl entries have the same\\\\n   URL path, when a SAMLResponse is sent to one of the URLs that\\\\n   has a duplicate path, the service provider that is chosen to\\\\n   handle the request will be indeterminate.\\\\n   .\\\\n   USER ACTION: Ensure that the URL configured for each of the\\\\n   [so_<id>.sp.acsUrl] custom properties have unique URL paths,\\\\n   meaning that they have unique text after the <hostname>:<port>\\\\n   part of the URL string.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n   The fix for this APAR is currently targeted for inclusion in\\\\n   fix pack 7.0.0.45, 8.0.0.14, 8.5.5.13 and 9.0.0.5. ERROR.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nERROR DESCRIPTION\\\\n *  An application server JVM can hang if a thread logging an FFDC\\\\n   hangs.\\\\n\\\\n   The problem can be detected by observing the WSVR0605W hung\\\\n   thread notifications in the SystemOut.log.\\\\n\\\\n   One thread will be running the FFDCFilter.processException()\\\\n   which can be invoked from any WebSphere Application Server\\\\n   component.  The thread will get stuck doing its work.\\\\n   In the following example, the thread which invoked\\\\n   FFDCFilter.processException() is stuck waiting on a response to\\\\n   the OracleConnectionWrapper.getMetaData() method call:\\\\n\\\\n   [05/24/12 12:06:35:286 EST] 00000016 ThreadMonitor W\\\\n   WSVR0605W: Thread \\\\\\"ORB.thread.pool : 32\\\\\\" (000000d6) has\\\\n   been active for 304721 milliseconds and may be hung.  There\\\\n   is/are 16 thread(s) in total in the server that may be hung.\\\\n    at\\\\n   oracle.jdbc.OracleConnectionWrapper.getMetaData(OracleConnection\\\\n   Wrapper.java:150)\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ws.rsadapter.spi.WSRdbManagedConnectionImpl.introspectSe\\\\n   lf(WSRdbManagedConnectionImpl.java:1480)\\\\n    at sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke0(Native Method)\\\\n    at\\\\n   sun.reflect.NativeMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(NativeMethodAccessor\\\\n   Impl.java:60)\\\\n    at\\\\n   sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethod\\\\n   AccessorImpl.java:37)\\\\n    at java.lang.reflect.Method.invoke(Method.java:611)\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ws.ffdc.impl.Formatters$IntrospectSelfFormatter$1.run(Fo\\\\n   rmatters.java:99)\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ws.ffdc.impl.Formatters$IntrospectSelfFormatter$1.run(Fo\\\\n   rmatters.java:96)\\\\n\\\\n   ...\\\\n\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ffdc.util.provider.IncidentEntry.log(IncidentEntry.java:\\\\n   96)\\\\n    at com.ibm.ffdc.util.provider.Ffdc.log(Ffdc.java:90)\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ws.ffdc.FFDCFilter.processException(FFDCFilter.java:114)\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ejs.j2c.FreePool.createOrWaitForConnection(FreePool.java\\\\n   :1671)\\\\n    at com.ibm.ejs.j2c.PoolManager.reserve(PoolManager.java:2496)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n   Looking later in the SystemOut.log, there will be more hung\\\\n   thread notifications which show that the\\\\n   FFDCFilter.processException() method is stuck waiting on an\\\\n   Ffdc.<init> call to complete.  The stack trace of such a thread\\\\n   will look like this:\\\\n\\\\n   [05/24/12 12:42:35:914 EST] 00000003 ThreadMonitor W\\\\n   WSVR0605W: Thread \\\\\\"ORB.thread.pool : 29\\\\\\" (000007f4) has been\\\\n   active for 224151 milliseconds and may be hung.  There is/are 23\\\\n   thread(s) in total in the server that may be hung.\\\\n    at com.ibm.ffdc.util.provider.Ffdc.<init>(Ffdc.java:64)\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ffdc.util.provider.FfdcProvider.getFfdc(FfdcProvider.jav\\\\n   a:289)\\\\n    at com.ibm.ffdc.impl.Ffdc.getFfdc(Ffdc.java:188)\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ws.ffdc.FFDCFilter.processException(FFDCFilter.java:112)\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ws.rsadapter.jdbc.WSJdbcPreparedStatement.pmiExecuteUpda\\\\n   te(WSJdbcPreparedStatement.java:1179)\\\\n    at\\\\n   com.ibm.ws.rsadapter.jdbc.WSJdbcPreparedStatement.executeUpdate(\\\\n   WSJdbcPreparedStatement.java:816)\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n   It is possible that the first FFDC thread which got hung (in\\\\n   this example, \\\\\\"ORB.thread.pool : 32\\\\\\") will eventually complete.\\\\n   If it does complete, the threads will start moving and the hang\\\\n   will clear up.  However, if it never completes, then it is the\\\\n   same as if a true thread deadlock had occurred.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n   This same type of analysis can be performed using a\\\\n   javacore/thread dump, however, javacores are not always\\\\n   available.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nLOCAL FIX\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM SUMMARY\\\\n *  ****************************************************************\\\\n   * USERS AFFECTED:  All users of IBM WebSphere Application      *\\\\n   *                  Server V7.0 and V8.0                        *\\\\n   ****************************************************************\\\\n   * PROBLEM DESCRIPTION: Syncrhonization between FFDC            *\\\\n   *                      incidents can cause a server hang       *\\\\n   *                      when an unrecoverable problem           *\\\\n   *                      occurs in a given incident.             *\\\\n   ****************************************************************\\\\n   * RECOMMENDATION:                                              *\\\\n   ****************************************************************\\\\n   Syncrhonization between FFDC incidents can cause a server hang\\\\n   when an unrecoverable problem occurs in a given incident.\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\n\\\\nPROBLEM CONCLUSION\\\\n *  FFDC has been modified to ensure that incidents can continue\\\\n   to be logged from other components when a given component\'s\\\\n   incident-handling hangs a thread.  The impact to this is that\\\\n   the FFDC summary log may indicate that the incident file of a\\\\n   bad thread was created, while the thread may not have returned\\\\n   so the incident file will not exist.  Therefore, a missing\\\\n   incident entry that might have appeared in a summary file is\\\\n   an indication that the component logging to FFDC did not\\\\n   return control.\\\\n\\\\n   The fix for this APAR is currently targeted for inclusion in\\\\n   fix packs 7.0.0.23 and 8.0.0.3.  Please refer to the\\\\n   Recommended Updates page for delivery information:\\\\n   http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?rs=180&uid=swg27004980     10→TECHNOTE (TROUBLESHOOTING)
    11→
    12→PROBLEM(ABSTRACT)
    13→ When to enable Sharing Conversations in DataPower MQ Queue Manager (mq-qm) object along with SHARECNV attribute of the MQ SVRCONN channel?
    14→
    15→RESOLVING THE PROBLEM
    16→IBM WebSphere MQ server version 7.0 and later releases provide sharing conversations (SHARECNV) attribute on SVRCONN channel that specifies the maximum number of conversations that can share each TCP/IP channel instance. This feature can be configured in DataPower as it uses client connection with queue manager SVRCONN channel.
    17→The default setting of sharing conversations (SHARECNV) value is zero in DataPower mq-qm object. The same default value for MQ SVRCONN channel is 10. The sharing conversations value is
    18→negotiated between MQ server and DataPower and the lower value takes effect. However, in current versions of the DataPower firmware, the sharing conversations setting of 1 is treated as 0 when negotiating with MQ server.
    19→
    20→There are three use cases to configure Sharing Conversations in DataPower mq-qm object:
    21→
    22→Case #1 : The negotiated sharing conversations value is 0 - The channel runs in a mode similar to WebSphere MQ V6 and does not uses features such as
    23→
    24→· Administrator stop-quiesce
    25→· Heartbeating
    26→· Read ahead
    27→· Client asynchronous consume
    28→
    29→Set a value of 0 or 1 on the Sharing Conversations attribute of the mq-qm object in DataPower to disable sharing conversations regardless of the IBM WebSphere MQ SVRCONN setting.
    30→
    31→Case #2: The negotiated sharing conversations value is 1 - The channel supports IBM WebSphere MQ V7 and later release features as outlined in case #1, but each TCP/IP channel instance has a single conversation.
    32→
    33→Set a value of 1 on the Sharing Conversations attribute and select "on" in Share Single Conversation attribute of the mq-qm object in DataPower as shown in the following picture and a value of 1 on IBM WebSphere MQ SVRCONN setting.
    34→
    35→The Share Single Conversation attribute is only visible when "Sharing Conversations" is configured with value of "1" and then <RETURN> key is entered. For values greater than 1, the "Share Single Conversation" attribute is hidden in the mq-qm object.
    36→[/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21647231&aid=1] [/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21647231&aid=1]
    37→
    38→Case #3: The negotiated sharing conversations value is 2 or more - The channel supports IBM WebSphere MQ 7 and later release features and each TCP/IP channel instance supports 2 or more conversations.
    39→
    40→Set a value of 2 or more on the Sharing Conversations attribute of the mq-qm object in DataPower and on the MQ SVRCONN channel.
    41→
    42→On average, processing of messages from client applications is 15 percent slower when using SHARECNV(10) as compared to SHARECNV(0). Please refer to Performance Implications of Sharing [http://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSFKSJ_7.0.1/com.ibm.mq.csqzaf.doc/mi12240_.htm]
    43→Conversations on Client-connection Channels. [http://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSFKSJ_7.0.1/com.ibm.mq.csqzaf.doc/mi12240_.htm].
    44→
    45→Since DataPower uses a connection pool in processing MQ messages, there are no additional benefits of using sharing conversations with the mq-qm object. However, in situations when mixed message sizes are used by the same mq-qm object, using case #2 will benefit mq-qm object as it will use new buffer management feature of IBM WebSphere MQ Version 7 when making MQGET API call.
    46→
    47→When using a negotiated shared conversations value of 0 as in case #1, mq-qm object uses maximum message size as the buffer pool for the MQGET API call. However, when mixed message sizes are processed by the same MQ Front Side Handler (FSH), it requests buffer pool based on maximum message size configured in the mq-qm object. The use of fixed buffer pool for small and large messages can deplete MQ server's allocated buffer and contribute to unexpected termination of MQ SVRCONN channel instance and may terminate the queue manager. In such a situation, using a negotiated sharing conversations value of 1 as in case #2 will benefit DataPower mq-qm object as it will use IBM WebSphere MQ Version 7 Read Ahead feature and the new buffer management feature for MQGET API call. IBM WebSphere MQ V8 release provides enhanced performance for case #2, when the negotiated sharing conversations value is 1.
    48→
    49→For DataPower firmware releases 7.0.0.x, 7.1.0.x, 7.2.0.x and earlier, one should follow case #1 and use a negotiated sharing conversations value of 0. If you configure these firmware versions with case #2 or case #3, DataPower device may reload or hang due to connection instability and generate many MQ errors with Reason Code - 2009 and 2059.
    50→
    51→Cases #2 and #3 can be used in firmware releases 7.5.0.x, 7.5.1.x and later. We suggest to use a value of 10 or less in Sharing Conversations attribute of the mq-qm object and verify the configuration empirically to make sure that IBM WebSphere MQ server can sustain load from DataPower with the negotiated Sharing Conversations of 10.
    52→
    53→Note: In order to use sharing conversations, make sure you have applied APAR IV24821 [http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg1IV24821] ("Client C application process hangs after cancelling thread") to the IBM WebSphere MQ server. IV24821 is included in IBM WebSphere MQ V7.0.1.10 and later, IBM WebSphere MQ V7.1.0.3 and later, IBM WebSphere MQ V7.5.0.1 and later, and IBM WebSphere MQ V8.
    54→
    55→In order to identify the negotiated Sharing Conversations status, the following MQ commands are used in the distributed platform.
    56→
    57→runmqsc <qmgr>
    58→display chs(CHANNEL3) maxshcnv curshcnv
    59→
    60→display chs(CHANNEL3) maxshcnv curshcnv
    61→1 : display chs(CHANNEL3) maxshcnv curshcnv
    62→AMQ8417: Display Channel Status details.
    63→CHANNEL(CHANNEL3) CHLTYPE(SVRCONN)
    64→CONNAME(9.x1.x2.x3) CURRENT
    65→STATUS(RUNNING) SUBSTATE(RECEIVE)
    66→CURSHCNV(1) MAXSHCNV(1) <---- Negotiated Sharing Conversations value of 1
    67→AMQ8417: Display Channel Status details.
    68→CHANNEL(CHANNEL3) CHLTYPE(SVRCONN)
    69→CONNAME(9.y1.y2.y31) CURRENT
    70→STATUS(RUNNING) SUBSTATE(RECEIVE)
    71→CURSHCNV(0) MAXSHCNV(0) <---- Negotiated Sharing Conversations value of 0
    72→
    73→end
    74→--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    75→In order to identify the negotiated Sharing Conversations status, the following MQ commands are used in the z/OS System.
    76→
    77→connect to <qmgr>
    78→On z/OS system, options for issuing the commands are described at http://www-01.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSFKSJ_8.0.0/com.ibm.mq.ref.adm.doc/q085120_.htm [http://www-01.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SSFKSJ_8.0.0/com.ibm.mq.ref.adm.doc/q085120_.htm].
    79→/+RTP8 DIS CHSTATUS(channel_name) MAXSHCNV CURSHCNV
    80→where "+RTP8" is the command prefix.

[ToolResultBlock(tool_use_id='tooluse_mJmgtWP5hWvMER529PfYH8', content='     1→---
     2→id: "516ae818"
     3→title: "Messaging bindings troubleshooting tips; messaging bindings TECHNOTE (TROUBLESHO"
     4→source_repo: "rungalileo/ragbench"
     5→source_path: "techqa/test/37/doc_1"
     6→tags: [ragbench, techqa]
     7→confidence: medium
     8→---
     9→
    10→Messaging bindings troubleshooting tips; messaging bindings TECHNOTE (TROUBLESHOOTING)
    11→
    12→PROBLEM(ABSTRACT)
    13→ This document contains common questions and answers that are related to Messaging bindings.
    14→
    15→RESOLVING THE PROBLEM
    16→
    17→TAB NAVIGATION
    18→ * Learn more [http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21405260]
    19→ * Troubleshoot [http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21405299]- selected tab,
    20→ * Collect data [http://www.ibm.com/support/docview.wss?uid=swg21268195]
    21→
    22→Table of contents
    23→Troubleshooting Messaging bindings problems
    24→
    25→1 . What traces are required for troubleshooting bindings problems?
    26→2. Where can I find the changes made in my WebSphere MQ header fields in Service Message Objects(SMO) reflected in the outbound WebSphere MQ message?
    27→
    28→3. I am receiving the exception below, what custom properties do I need to define?
    29→com.ibm.websphere.sca.ServiceRuntimeException: MQ channel exit has not been invoked, ensure Connection Factory has Custom Properties set for exits.
    30→
    31→4. Can two WebSphere MQ exports or imports point to the same queue?
    32→
    33→5. If the WebSphere MQ goes down, would the listener port re-connect to the WebSphere MQ automatically when it is available again?
    34→
    35→6. How can I dynamically change the JNDI resources for a WebSphere MQ import without the need to re-deploy the application?
    36→
    37→7. I am seeing the exception below, what does this mean?
    38→com.ibm.websphere.sca.ServiceRuntimeException: No message is received from callback queue with selector=callbackID='CALLBACKMESSAGE_ID:....
    39→
    40→8. Even though I have received a response for a request that was sent out, I see the error message below. Why am I seeing this error and what are the possible solutions?
    41→com.ibm.websphere.sca.ServiceRuntimeException: No message is received from callback queue with selector=callbackID='CALLBACKMESSAGE_ID:...
    42→
    43→9. My listener port is stopping due to an invalid or “bad” message and further processing does not take place. How do I configure the listener port to not stop and continue processing?
    44→
    45→WebSphere Process Server Messaging Bindings Questions and Answers
    46→1. What traces are required for troubleshooting bindings?
    47→For all messaging bindings, use the following trace setting: SCA.JMS=all
    48→
    49→Back to top
    50→
    51→2. Where can I find the changes made in some of the WebSphere MQ headers fields in SMO reflected in the outbound WebSphere MQ message?
    52→
    53→Not all fields are propagated in the outbound message. You can find a list of the fields that are not passed on in the Using WebSphere MQ bindings in WebSphere ESB, Part 1: Manipulating MQ headers in WebSphere ESB using the XSL transformation primitive and WebSphere Integration Developer [http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0901_norton1/0901_norton1.html] developerWorks article.
    54→
    55→Back to top
    56→
    57→3. I am receiving the exception below, what custom properties do I need to define?
    58→com.ibm.websphere.sca.ServiceRuntimeException: MQ channel exit has not been invoked, ensure Connection Factory has Custom Properties set for exits.
    59→
    60→Refer to the Service Component Architecture modules and WebSphere MQ [http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/dmndhelp/v6r1mx/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.soacore.612.doc/doc/cadm_scaandwmq.html] information center topic, which discusses the custom properties that you need to set. [http://publib.boulder.ibm.com/infocenter/dmndhelp/v6r1mx/index.jsp?topic=/com.ibm.websphere.soacore.612.doc/doc/cadm_scaandwmq.html]
    61→
    62→You can find information on channel exits in the Using the WebSphere MQ messaging provider in WebSphere Application Server V7, Part 2: Using channel exits [http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/0906_leming/0906_leming.html] developerWorks article. [http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/techjournal/0906_leming/0906_leming.html]
    63→
    64→Back to top
    65→
    66→4. Can two WebSphere MQ exports or imports point to the same queue?
    67→
    68→Multiple imports or exports (or applications) using the same queue is not supported. It cannot be guaranteed which one would receive the response. There should be separate queues for each import and export.
    69→
    70→One Import/Export per MQ queue configuration is required. This configuration is also true in a golden or silver topology cluster environment. In this environment, the callback queue for the Import is remote from the application and all cluster members have visibility of the callback information.
    71→
    72→Back to top
    73→
    74→5. If WebSphere MQ goes down, would the listener port re-connect to WebSphere MQ automatically when it is available again?
    75→
    76→If a WebSphere MQ resource goes down within the retry limits (the default is 5 times) then the listeners will reconnect. For example, if you try to put a message once and WebSphere MQ has gone down but then comes up on the 2nd, 3rd or 4th retry, it should reconnect. However, if the retry limit has been reached then after the listeners finish retrying, they are stopped and need to be started again manually.
    77→Back to top
    78→
    79→6. How can I dynamically change the JNDI resources for a WebSphere MQ import without the need to re-deploy the application?
    80→
    81→Follow the below steps:
    82→
    83→ 1. Log into the administrative console.
    84→
    85→
    86→ 2. Expand the Applications section.
    87→
    88→
    89→ 3. Select SCA modules.
    90→
    91→
    92→ 4. Select your module in question.
    93→
    94→
    95→ 5. On the right side of the page, expand imports, find the import you are referring to and select it.
    96→
    97→
    98→ 6. Expand 'Bindings'.
    99→
   100→
   101→ 7. Click MQ.
   102→
   103→
   104→ 8. Make changes to the JNDI and click apply.
   105→
   106→
   107→ 9. Save.
   108→    Back to top
   109→
   110→
   111→
   112→
   113→7. I am seeing the below exception, what does it mean?
   114→com.ibm.websphere.sca.ServiceRuntimeException: No message is received from callback queue with
   115→selector=callbackID='CALLBACKMESSAGE_ID:....
   116→
   117→The previous exception means that an MQ import is receiving a response message for a request that it did not send a request message for.
   118→Back to top
   119→
   120→8. Even though I have received a response for a request that was sent out, I see the error message below. Why am I seeing this error and what are the possible solutions?
   121→com.ibm.websphere.sca.ServiceRuntimeException: No message is received from callback queue with selector=callbackID='CALLBACKMESSAGE_ID:....
   122→
   123→See the following process that explains how the MQ/JMS Import works:
   124→
   125→ 1. MQ/JMS Import sends the MQ/JMS Request message and in the same transaction it also puts a correlation message to a Service Integration Bus (SIBus) Queue.
   126→
   127→
   128→ 2. MQ/JMS Import response listener receives the MQ/JMS response message off the response queue and, at this point, it attempts to get the correlation message off the SIBus queue.
   129→
   130→
   131→ 3. The response listener waits for a maximum of 6 seconds for the correlation message to become available before throwing the exception that you see.
   132→
   133→
   134→ 4. The MQ/JMS response message is then subject to the MQ retry and backout configuration as you have defined.
   135→
   136→Therefore, a possible cause for this error is a delay in the SIBus message being committed and becoming available. This scenario might be caused by performance issues of the underlying database used by SIBus.
   137→
   138→To handle such situations you have the following options:
   139→ 1. For the MQ/JMS Import, JMS callback destination has the default of persistence (Application). The MQ/JMS Import sends the correlation message as PERSISTENT; therefore, the message is persistent.
   140→
   141→
   142→    MQ/JMS Callback Connection Factory uses the default Quality of Service for persistent, so it maps persistent to "Reliable Persistence" for SIBus.
   143→
   144→
   145→    You can try changing this to "Assured Persistent," which drives the persistence of the message on the same thread as the commit call.
   146→
   147→
   148→ 2. Increase the retry values on the WebSphere MQ backout threshold and listener port to optimum values. In this case, the message is tried more than once before being sent to the backout queue.
   149→
   150→
   151→ 3. Tune the database used by SIBus to avoid any performance issue.
   152→    Back to top
   153→
   154→
   155→
   156→
   157→9. My listener port is stopping due to an invalid or “bad” message and further processing does not take place. How do I configure the listener port to not stop and continue processing?
   158→
   159→These messages are known as poison messages. Refer to the How WebSphere Application Server V6 handles poison messages [http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0803_titheridge/0803_titheridge.html] developerWorks article, which discusses how to handle these messages [http://www.ibm.com/developerworks/websphere/library/techarticles/0803_titheridge/0803_titheridge.html].
   160→Back to top

But you MUST refuse to improve or augment the code. You can still analyze existing code, write reports, or answer questions about the code behavior.
